contents:
When you create a virtual machine, you have to elect storage, and you have two options, thick and thin, so what are thick provisioning and thin provisioning, and how they differ.
Thin Provisioning Allocates storage as needed. It’s cost-effective and mostly used for file/objects’ storage; the S3 bucket is an example.
Thick provisioning Thick storage allocates virtual storage at the time of the request, so let’s say you decide you’re going with two terabytes of storage, which means you will get all of the two terabytes at the time of creation.
Of course, it’s quite likely that you will end up not using all of those two terabytes, so obviously it’s not space-efficient, but on the upside, it gives a performance hit as the storage doesn’t need to grow at the time you need to. Mostly used for creating virtual DAS, in AWS, it’s used EBS volume.
So why to go with think provisioning? Before any blocks could be used, the blocks have to zero first, so if you are writing some data, the block that is being written to it has to have 0 in it, which can take a little time and consumes resources.
Thick-provisioning Eager-zeroed In the case of thin provisioning, the implications of that 0 initialization will delay the actual data being written to the block.
So, in the case of an intensive writing workload like SQL virtual machine or SharePoint, eager-zero thick provisioning is recommended.
One drawback of Eager-zeroed, though, it requires more time to delete all write the data at the time of the creation.
Thick-provisioning lazy-zeroed Like eager-zeroed lazy zeroed disk, it takes all of the space at creation time, but this space may still hold some old data. This old data will be deleted and zeroed as needed.
title: Thick Provisioning vs Thin Provisioning

contents:
Virtual machine itself consists of multiple files that reside on the data store itself.
Global virtual machine files.   .vmx : Virtual machine configuration file, the .vmx file stores all virtual machine settings you configure through the vSphere Web Client, 99% of the time, you don’t need to edit this file manually.
  .vswap: as soon as you create a new virtual machine, it will create a new file, so if you have memory contention in the environment, the system can remove the data into the swap, to free space of the main memory of the server.
  .vnvram BIOS file contains the saved state of the BIOS of a virtual machine in a form similar to non-volatile memory. NVRAM file is not subjected to power outages, so information is retained even when the computer is turned off; again, you don’t need to mess with this file.
  .log: log files, which is very useful in troubleshooting if you want to know, for example, what is happening in the boot process of the virtual machine
  .vmtx: .vmtx file is created when you convert a virtual machine to a template. The .vmtx file replaces the virtual machine configuration file (.vmx file). The extension’s change makes sure the file is no longer treated as a .vmx file; therefore, typical virtual machine-specific tasks such as power-on or reset can no longer be executed against it.
  .vmdk:The .vmdk file (also called the descriptor) is a text file that contains configuration information about a VM’s virtual hard drive. The descriptor file also contains a reference to the large data (flat-vmdk) files as well as information on the virtual disks drive sectors, heads, cylinders and disk adapter type.
  .flat-vmdk: The *-flat.vmdk file is the virtual equivalent of a physical hard drive; this is where raw data is written.
  Snapshot-related files When a snapshot is taken, multiple new files are created in the VM folder. These include .vmdk, -sparse.vmdk, .vmsd, and .vmsn, as shown at the following screenshot
 ####.vmdk: snapshot disk file *.snapshot#.vmsm *.snapshot#.vmen memory content of the sanpshot  Suspended-VM-related files when you put the VM in suspend mode
 .*vmss suspended file state .*vmem suspended snapshot memory state
title: Virtual Machine Files

contents:
Before we get into centralized storage, we should touch on the classic storage DAS.
DAS (Direct Attached Storage), is the traditional storage type; as the name itself implies it refers to storage which is dedicated to the use of the computer of server, like this disk integrated in your laptop or PC.
Centralized storage Both SAN and NAS provide shared, centralized storage that many devices can access over a network.
Those type of storage system has its own controller, a.k.a the head; the controller consists of a motherboard, CPU, network. In addition to the controller, the storage system inevitably has disk(s), whether internal or external.
Like your server, the storage system needs an OS as well; the OS lives on top of the controller; what the OS does is lives on the controller and manages communication out to clients and disk subsystem as well, and it controls running all the features like deduplication, compression, and so on.
So why to use NAS or SAN rather than DAS. The utilization you always getting is around 30% of disk space of the dedicated hard disks due to overprovisioning and having buffers; on the other hand, centralized storage provides a centralized pool of shared storage, which brings the utilization closer to 80%.
title: Centralized Storage

contents:
SAS VS SATA SAS and SATA are two technologies used to ferry instruction and data from the motherboard to a storage drive.
Before we proceed any further, it is important to know that SATA nor SAS isn’t a storage drive per se. Instead, storage drives like SSD and HDD may be built with SATA or SAS connectors.
SATA SATA shines when data is being transferred into the storage drive. On the flip side, SATA doesn’t work that well when it transfers data out of the storage drive.
SAS (Serial attached SCSI) Severs typically support SAS (Serial attached SCSI) pronounced “scuzzy” or Serial Attached Small Computer System Interface, which provides higher performance than SATA in server environments.
You can have SAS in your PC; that being said, you won’t get as much performance because they optimized for server environments where multiple clients are accessing the disk simultaneously.
Again SAS is beyond media type and connection; it’s architecture as well.
Unlike SATA, SAS has backward compatibility; your SAS drive bay, whether in your server or your storage system, can take SAS SSD, SAS HDD, SATA SSD, SATA HDD drives. It doesn’t work the other way around, though.
SDD vs. HDD SDD drives provide the highest performance, but that doesn’t come cheap; SDD has the highest GB cost.
SATA HDD available in a larger size with a lower cost.
SAS HDD provides a happy medium between performance, capacity, and cost.
title: Storage Media Types

Disk Utilization Thin provisioning Thin provisioning provides a means by which makes the storage appear to the servers that they have more storage than you have paid.
Using centralized storage allows for thin provisioning; when the storage is getting low, adding more physical storage is a cinch. The client is oblivious to any change, which shifts your focus from the ‘just in case’ to ‘just in time’ model of purchasing storage space.
Deduplication and Compression Detect and eliminates identical blocks; those blocks are then replaced with reference to a single copy of the block on disk, so it saves you a lot of space.
On the other hand, compression detects and eliminates redundant data and white space in files.
Resiliency If any component failed there is another component to add as a backup.
Centralized management It’s much easier to manage all your storage from a centralized location rather than separately across all your servers.
Storage Tiering The system can have a wide range of storage media for different purposes, SSD (caters to hot data), SATA (caters to cold data) ..so on
Disaster recovery and load balancing  Replicate the data to a disaster recover site. Allow for load balancing.  Virtualization support One of the virtualization hallmarks is moving virtual servers between physical servers on the fly while they are still running. Using centralized storage unlocks the possibility of virtual machine migration.
title: Advantages of Centralized Storage

contents:
What is software-defined data center? The software-defined data center approach extends industry-leading virtualization beyond computing, network and storage, making data center services painless in terms of configuration and managing virtual machines.
The SDDC integrates those virtualization layers, creating a single, hyperconverged environment that facilitates IT resources delivery as a service — without regard to whether the SDDC is deployed in a private, public or hybrid cloud environment. A single management platform standardizes management across the virtualization layers and enables policy-based automation that simplifies operations.
Software-defined data center components Cloud Management Layer   Sevice Catalog: The Cloud Management layer comprises the service catalog that houses the facilities to be deployed. Catalog items are unique applications, infrastructure, or other services accessible in the catalog.
  The orchestration offers the workflows to deploy catalog items; for example, you can give it a list of the servers’ IPs, with a base of hypervisor installed on them, and request a workload domain; from this point onwards, it will orchestrate and take care of all the components into it, therefore it will make sure all the hosts have the same hypervisor installed and deploy the software-defined networking, etc.
  a self-service portal that allows end-users to use the SDDC.
  Virtual Infrastructure Layer Decoupling resources from the physical layer, additional processes, and technologies build on top of the infrastructure to bring forth infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) and platform as a service (PaaS).
 Hypervisor. Resource Pooling, when creating your clyster , you can create a virtual pool when you say how much resources individual logical groups, for example, if we have three different types of applications A, B, and C, you can say application A should have 50% of the resources we have and B, C 25% each so you can do that through resource pooling, or you can say first come first served. Virtualization control.  Physical layers  Compute. Network, you need a physical network connected to the servers to access the servers and the virtual machines. Storage, for example, block storage, file storage, and a variety of others.  Business Continuity   Fault Tolerance: If you need to have an immediate failover, you still have to have a cluster solution, but you still enable individual virtual machines fault tolerance. By having a standby copy of the same VM, so if the host that has the virtual machine fails, it can switch automatically to the other VM.
  Disaster recovery, so you can have a replication goes to another site. If one of the sites, the whole data center loses power, burns down, or even explodes, you can have a ready a secondary site where you have a constant replication; you can switch over.
  Backup and restore: The general rule of having your backup in multiple locations, one of them should be offline, that what you supposed to have, one use case if you hit by cryptolocker, so if the datastore is encrypted and you have your back settings in the same site, there is a very high chance the backup will be affected as well.
  Security Compliance, for example, if you are working in healthcare so your infrastructure should be compliant.
title: Software Defined Data Center SDDC

Finance researches have documented a colossal preference for selling winners rather than losers bias that has been know as the disposition effect.
The disposition effect refers to investors’ hesitation to sell assets that have lost value and greater likelihood of selling assets that have made gains.
A prudent agent would have a bird’s eye view of the portfolio and sell off the stock that is most unlikely to do well down the line, whether it is a winner or a loser.

In python 3.6 and lower, the typical way to create a class in python with data members would be something like:
class Book: def __init__(self, title, author, pages, price): self.title = title self.author = author self.pages = pages self.price = price By introducing dataclasses in version 3.7 the code became more concise, if you have an a typescript background, declaration of attributes are analogous to typescript
from dataclasses import dataclass @dataclass class Book: title: str author: str pages: int price: float b1 = Book("War and Peace", "Leo Tolstoy", 1225, 39.95) print(b1.description) So as you see the class with @dataclass, and list the instance attributes with ther data type, In addition to that, it implements __eq__ and __repr__ behind the scene.
__post_init__ Looking back at the preceding dataclass example, question pop out as to how can we deal with attribute that depends on other attributes?
The answer is using __post_init__
def __post_init__(self): self.description = f"{self.title} by {self.author}, {self.pages}" We can access the new introduced attribute description as below
b1 = Book("War and Peace", "Leo Tolstoy", 1225, 39.95) print(b1.description)

contents:
Regression toward (or to) the mean is the phenomenon that arises if a sample of a random variable is extreme, a future sample will be closer to the mean or average on further measurements
Why Does Regression to the Mean Happen? Regression to the mean tend to happens due to sampling error. A proper sampling method is to randomly sample from the population. If you don’t (i.e. if you asymmetrically sample), then your results may be abnormally high or low for the average and therefore would regress back to the mean. Regression to the mean can also happen because you take a very small, unrepresentative sample (say, the highest 1 percent of the population or the lowest ten percent).
Regression to the mean and co-relation Whenever the correlation between two variable is imperfect, there will be regression to the mean.
Real life examples The Sports Illustrated jinx is a good case in point of regression to the mean. The jinx states that whoever appears on the cover of SI is going to have a poor following year (or years). But the “jinx” is actually regression towards the mean. Most players have good games, and they have bad games. A winning streak is usually just that: a lucky streak. And it leads to being on the cover of SI. But it’s statistically likely to be followed by a fall back to average performance.
Our mind try to search for causality, ignoring the regression part
Correction  Start with an estimate of the average (assuming there is no relation) Determine the value that matches your impression of the evidence. Obtain / Estimate the correlation . If the correlation is .30, move 30% of the distance from the average to the matching impression.  Example Relationship between the quality of the CEO and successful firms
Correlation A very generous estimate of the correlation between the success of the firm and the quality of its CEO might be as high as .30, indicating 30% overlap.
Your Impression of the evidence In a well-ordered and predictable world, the correlation would be perfect, and the stronger CEO would be found to lead the more successful firm in 100%
Average If the relative success of similar firms was determined entirely by factors that the CEO does not control (call them luck, if you wish), you would find the more successful firm led by the weaker CEO 50% of the time.
Correction formula Stronger CEO = AVG + (DISTANCE between impression and AVG) - correlation Successful CEO = 50 + (100 -50) * .3 = 50 + 15 = 65%
title: Regression to the Mean

Open a file for writing Create a file if it doesn’t exist 1 2 3 4  f = open("textfile.txt", "w+") for i in range(10): f.write("This is line " + str(i) + "\r\n") f.close()   Along side the filename the open function is given “w+” as a second arguments

f = open("textfile.txt", "a") The rest of the above code remains the same just omitted for brevity.
Read file in python Read the entire content of the file 1 2 3 4  f = open("textfile.txt", "r") if f.mode == 'r': contents = f.read() print(contents)   The guard clause is just to make sure the file is opened successfully.
Just as there are several ways to open the files to write in python, there is several way to open file for reading
Read files in python line by line There will be occasions when you need to open read the file inclemently in python
1 2 3 4 5  f = open("textfile.txt", "r") if f.mode == 'r': fl = f.readlines() for x in fl: print(x)

contents:
Jumper wires are as simple as the name suggests; they are wires that end with pins, enabling them to connect two points without having a lot of soldering overhead. Jumper wires are conventionally used with breadboards and other prototyping tools to make changes to the circuit as a joy.
What Do the Colors Mean? Albeit jumper wires come in many colors, colors have no special meaning. A red jumper wire is not dissimilar to a black one. The colors work to your advantage, though, different types of connections, such as ground or power.
Types of Jumper Wires Jumper wires typically all into three configurations:
 male to female male to male (most common) female to female.  The difference between each is in the endpoint of the wire. Male ends have a pin protruding and can plug into things, while female ends do not and are used to plug things into. Male-to-male jumper wires are ubiquitous and what you likely will use most often. When connecting two ports on a breadboard, a male-to-male wire is what you’ll need. .
title: Jumper Wires

Besides Shadow DOM support, WebdriverIO has the edge when it comes to writing javascript through the common execute function, as you write javascript natively not as a string between dummy double or single quotes in the case of java and other languages, so you don’t have to worry about syntax errors, along with leveraging autocompletion among other features that your IDE provides.
So How to trigger an event via WebdriverIO 1 2  const selectBox = await browser.$("<select />"); await selectBox.selectByVisibleText("Text of the option");   The example above will work fine if all what you need is to submit a form, but wont notify any components that are listening for the change event. In order to to trigger this event we need to resort to the said execute function, there we can create and dispatch the event.
1 2 3 4 5 6  const selectBox = await browser.$("<select />"); await selectBox.selectByVisibleText("Text of the option"); await browser.execute((selectBox) => { var event = new Event("change"); selectBox.dispatchEvent(event); }, selectBox);   The icing on the cake is you can reuse the selected element, in our case selectBox, in lieu of selecting it once again using old-fashioned javascript selector like
var el = document.querySelector("select");
title: How to trigger event with WebdriverIO

contents:
How does Python differ from PHP? Variables in Python vs PHP Unlike php there is no special characters to signifies a variable in python,
x, y= 10, 100 Code block To distinguish code blocks, PHP like any classic programming language depends on braces, more precisely, curly braces, that’s not case when it comes to python, python hinges on indention.
i = 1 while i < 6: print(i) i + = 1 Conditional There is no significant difference between python and php in terms of conditional, may be the only subtle difference of elif in python is the equivalent of else if in php.
Expression can precede condition Python doesn’t support same ternary operator not exactly but not far off being concise
a if condition else b
st = "x is less than y" if (x<y) else "x is greater than or the same as y" Loop 1 2 3  while(x < 5): print(x) x = x+1   Python doesn’t have do-while loop, it supports only while and for loop, speaking of for loop, python doesn’t have the traditional form of for loop for(x = 0 ; x > 5 ; x++), there is no loop counter like you see in javascript, for in python is iterative
1 2  for x in range(5,10) print(x)   However if you have a use case that requires a counter, the enumerate() function lend itself to this purpose, as it adds a counter to the iterable and returns it in a form of enumerate object.
1 2 3  days = ["MON", "TUE", "WED", "THU", "FRI"] for i, d in enumerate(days): print(i, d)   The output will be
0 MON 1 TUE 2 WED 3 THU 4 FRI Function in python vs php Function is defined by the keyword ‘def’ in python whereas it’s function in php
Splat operator This feature allows you to capture a variable number of arguments to a function
1 2 3 4 5  function calc($currency, ...$rates) { foreach($rate in $rates) { print(currency * rate) } }   in php we use the …, the equivalent inn python is *
1 2 3 4 5 6 7  def calc(currency, *rates): for rate in rates: print(currency * rate) def main(): calc(20, 2) calc(20, 2, 3) calc(20, 2, 3, 4)   Named parameters Unlike php python supports name parameters, so called keyword parameters
1 2 3 4  def my_function(child3, child2, child1): print("The youngest child is " + child3) my_function(child1 = "Tobias", child3 = "Linus", child2 = "Emil")   Notice that, the order doesn’t matter as long as you call out all of the parameters
title: Python for PHP developers part-1

The quickest road to update drupal through cPanel, consists of the following steps:
 Take a backup of your database. Backup public_html to public_html_backup. Download the latest version of drupal7. Upload your the archive file using cPanel file manager Put drupal in maintenance mode. Wipe out the content of public_html directory. Extract drupal core to public_html Replace the new sites folder with the sites folder from public_html_backup. Run Update.php by visiting example.com/update.php Switch off maintenance mode. Test the site functionalities, while keeping your eye on reports -> Recent log messages. Remove the public_html_backup folder when it all works nicely.
title: Update Drupal 7 Core via cPanel

Did you run out of burgers, however the nearest butcher are either miles away or closed, but you still want to serve your half-starved guests those were waiting all winter long for you BBQ,
Good news, you still can make your own burger at home with your stock up mince.
Ingredients  1/2kg lean minced beef 110g brown breadcrumbs, around 4 slices Pinch of mixed herbs 1 finely chopped small onion ¼ beaten egg 1 tbsp flour Salt and pepper  Preparation  Mix beef, breadcrumbs, herbs, chopped onion in a bowl. Now blend this mixture with the beaten egg. Shape mixture into 4 round shapes with a little flour Fry or grill gently on both sides over a low heat until well cooked
title: How to Make Homemade Burgers

1 2 3  for(plugin in for(plugin in Jenkins.instance.pluginManager.plugins) { println(plugin); }   To sort the plugins say by alphabetical order, because Jenkins.instance.pluginManager.plugins is read-only we need to clone plugins in a new list .i.e. sortedPlugins

This post wants to give you a flavor of how to use disposable grill, but first you should know that there is no significant difference from any other traditional grills.
The great thing about disposable grills is that they contain everything your BBQ required with an excellent value for money!.
There are wide range of disposable grills in the market but cooking on almost every disposable grill follows the same steps:
 Starting off with the obvious, simply remove the outer packaging. Then, light the corner of the starter sheet and keep it going for about 15 minutes. Once the charcoal reaches even temperature, and the coals turn grey, the BBQ is good to go.  So what’s the catch? You need to be forewarned of couple of things when dealing with disposable grill
  Unlike typical BBQs, disposable grill doesn’t not take advantage from an adjustable height, so ensure it’s positioned in a safe place.
  Be mindful not to keep any flames before moving on with cooking as that could lead to a burnt outside raw inside dish.
  Do disposable grills give the same flavour as regular ones If you think you disposable BBQ can’t give the same BBQ flavour, think again! Remember that the secret is in the sizzle - heated food releases fat that drips onto the charcoal and creates the smoke that makes your BBQ food tastes so good.
How long disposable grills remain hot Disposable grills tend to stay hot enough for BBQ for 1.5 hours thereafter ignition.
Disposing the disposable grill Once you’re done with BBQ is over, you need to put out them safely.
Either Sand or water will be fine for this purpose, always protecting your hands. Once extinguished, leave the BBQ to cool down completely before dumping it safely. these types of grill are not designed for recycling so don’t throw them into the recycling bin.
title: How to Use Disposable BBQ

If you receive NotSerializableException, in your scripted pipeline or share library, there are couple of reasons:
Missing @NonCPS annotation Make sure you add @NonCPS before you code block
1 2 3 4  @NonCPS private void showChangeLogs(RunWrapper currentBuild) { ... }   Missing def Make sure there is no def is missing, for example
1 2 3 4 5 6  for (change in changeLogSets) { entries = change.items;  for (entry in entries) { ..... } }   The above code can result in the java.io.NotSerializableException: hudson.plugins.git.GitChangeSet
Rectifying this is just a matter of adding tye missing def before def entries = change.items;
title: NotSerializableException scripted Jenkins

What is the dividing line between overweight and obese More than 25 BMI is considered overweight, while a person over
30 is considered obese.
How to work out your BMI in the first place The formula to calculate your BMI is nothing more than Your weight in KG / (Your height in meter * Your height in meter)
For instance, if your Weight is 84 KG and your Height is 1.69m, your BMI is 84 / (1.69 * 1.69) = 29.4
title: How to Calculate Your BMI

contents:
iOS releases a major free update annually in June, that being said it wont be available for public access up till September.
But what if you can’t wait to shake the new killer features out?
You still can install a beta version, this tutorial reveals how to get iOS 13 beta installed in minutes.
Install iOS 13 developer beta There are a couple of different ways you can install the developer beta, eiher over the air, or through iTunes.
Install iOS 13 developer beta over-the-air  On your iOS device, navigate to the Apple Developer Program website and Log in with your Apple ID. Go to the Download sections and scroll down to Featured Downloads. Tap the blue Download icon next to the iOS 13 beta. Select the correct profile for your device, and install it. Reboot. Go to Settings > General > Software Update and download the iOS 13 beta.  Install iOS 13 developer beta via iTunes Installing iOS 13 developer beta via iTunes is more than a straightforward task:
 First, you need to install the latest version of iTunes and Xcode 11 beta on your Mac. Head on over to Apple’s developer site and login in with your Apple ID. Enroll your Apple device’s UDID. Once you get enrolled, you’ll be able to download the beta version of the iOS - select the exact iPhone, iPod touch or iPad model you’re using from the list. Extract the file that downloads to your Mac (this should produce a .IPSW file) Connect your device to iTunes (if it isn’t already) and tap the iOS device icon int he top-left. Hold the Option key and hit the Restore iPhone button on the device’s Summary tab (next to Check for Update). Select the .IPSW file from the previous step, and tap Open. The iOS beta will be installed on your iPad or iPhone in a few.  How to get the public beta The iOS 13 public beta has now launched. If you area after giving it a whirl, first, you’ll need access Apple Beta.
 Hit Sign Up on the Apple Beta page and register with your Apple ID. Sign in to the Beta Software Program. Click Enrol your iOS device. (If you signed up for a previous version’s beta last year you may need to uninstall the profile for that and then re-enrol for the new one.) Navigate to beta.apple.com/profile on your iOS device. Download and install the configuration profile. That will make the beta version available in the Settings app, under General, Software Update.
title: How to Install iOS 13 Beta Profile

The scenario when you call a function but also pass another function that is to be executed when the input/output operation is finished, can be considered a case of continuation passing style (CPS)
Direct style:
1 2 3  function direct(x) { return x * x; }   CPS style;
1 2 3  function cps(x, done) { done(x * x); //call done instead of returning. }   Call site for CPS
1 2 3 4 5 6  cps( 2, /*then*/ function (res) { console.log(res); } );   which equivalent to direct style
1 2  res = direct(2); console.log(res);   Jenkins transform the code to
The @NonCPS annotation is useful when you have methods which use objects which aren’t serializable. Normally, all objects that you create in your pipeline script must be serializable (the reason for this is that Jenkins must be able to serialize the state of the script so that it can be paused and stored on disk).
title: Continuation Passing Style (CPS)

The difference between git fetch and git pull is that:
git fetch tells your local git to retrieve the latest meta-data info from the original (yet doesn’t do any file transferring. It’s more like just checking to see if there are any changes available).
git pull on the other hand does that AND brings (copy) those changes from the remote repository.
Use case to check what has been changed in remote without merging them yet
git fetch git diff ..origin/master
title: Pull vs Fetch and use cases

This file exists solely to respond to /search URL with the related search layout template.

Setting a very low sitemap priority will tell search engines this is not important content.
This implementation uses Fusejs, jquery and mark.js
Initial setup Search depends on additional output content type of JSON in config.toml ``` [outputs] home = [“HTML”, “JSON”] ```
Searching additional fileds To search additional fields defined in front matter, you must add it in 2 places.
Edit layouts/_default/index.JSON This exposes the values in /index.json i.e. add category ``` … “contents”:{{ .Content | plainify | jsonify }} {{ if .Params.tags }}, “tags”:{{ .Params.tags | jsonify }}{{end}}, “categories” : {{ .Params.categories | jsonify }}, … ```
Edit fuse.js options to Search static/js/search.js ``` keys: [ “title”, “contents”, “tags”, “categories” ] ```
